current_fact.fact_text: On 21 February 1958, British designer Gerald Holtom finished the symbol that would become globally known as the peace sign. Its shape encodes the semaphore letters N and D for “nuclear disarmament”, with the circle representing the world—a graphic born from protest that quietly became a universal language of hope.

queue.fact_text: On 21 February 1947, inventor Edwin H. Land stunned an audience in New York by demonstrating the first Polaroid Land Camera, which could produce a finished photograph in under a minute. His idea came from his young daughter asking why she couldn’t see a photo right away—a child’s question that compressed darkroom magic into something almost instant.

episode.title: Morning Drops #27 - Nomophobia
episode.description: Yasmin reflects on what happened when she recently lost her phone and why it felt freeing. An invitation to rethink how we connect and disconnect.

queue.fact_text: On 21 February 1995, adventurer Steve Fossett completed the first solo hot‑air balloon flight across the Pacific Ocean, drifting from South Korea to a frozen field near Leader, Saskatchewan. Alone in a small capsule under a thin envelope of heated air, he rode jet streams for over 9,600 kilometers, turning the sky itself into a slow, fragile highway.

episode.title: Morning Drops #31 - Sailing With Germans

queue.fact_text: On 21 February 1945, the Brazilian Expeditionary Force finally captured Monte Castello in Italy after several failed attempts in snow and fog. It was a rare moment when South American troops fought and died on European soil, leaving a little‑known Brazilian imprint on the mountainous Italian landscape of World War II.

queue.fact_text: On 21 February 2022, days before Russia’s full‑scale invasion, Vladimir Putin declared the self‑proclaimed Luhansk and Donetsk republics independent from Ukraine and ordered troops into the region. It was a televised speech that tried to rewrite borders and history in real time, while the world watched a new phase of an old conflict take shape.

queue.fact_text: On 21 February 1945, during the Battle of Iwo Jima, Japanese kamikaze pilots sank the escort carrier USS Bismarck Sea and badly damaged the USS Saratoga. These deliberate one‑way missions were a grim fusion of technology and human sacrifice, turning aircraft into guided weapons flown by young men who did not plan to return.

queue.fact_text: On 21 February 1937, the League of Nations voted to ban foreign volunteers from fighting in the Spanish Civil War. The decision was meant to limit escalation, but in practice it tried to stem the flow of idealists from dozens of countries who saw Spain as the frontline between rising fascism and fragile democracy.

queue.fact_text: On 21 February 1929, warlord Zhang Zongchang led 24,000 rebels in northeastern Shandong, only to be defeated by a Nationalist force less than a third of that size at Zhifu. The clash was part of China’s chaotic Warlord Era, when maps were less about borders and more about which local strongman controlled the nearest railway or city gate.

queue.fact_text: On 21 February 1973, Israeli fighter jets shot down Libyan Arab Airlines Flight 114 after the airliner strayed over the Sinai Peninsula in bad weather and navigational confusion, killing 108 people. It’s a stark reminder that in tense airspace, a few wrong signals and misread coordinates can turn civilian travel into a battlefield in minutes.

queue.fact_text: On 21 February 1918, the last known Carolina parakeet—a bright green parrot once common in the eastern United States—died in the Cincinnati Zoo. Within a century, a noisy, fruit‑loving flock that had painted North American forests in neon colors vanished completely, largely due to habitat loss and hunting.

episode.title: Morning Drops #40 - Diving With Orcas

queue.match_reason: An extinction story born from human impact on wildlife pairs with an episode dedicated to intimate encounters with wild marine animals, honoring the species we still have and the ones we’ve already lost.

queue.fact_text: On 21 February 1848, a slim pamphlet titled *The Communist Manifesto* was published in London, arguing that history was a struggle between classes and ending with the famous call, “Workers of the world, unite!” Originally printed in German for a small radical circle, its ideas would echo across revolutions and political movements for generations.

queue.fact_text: On 21 February 2013, twin bomb blasts ripped through a busy market area in Hyderabad, India, killing at least 17 people and injuring over a hundred. The attacks struck in the early evening, turning a familiar urban rhythm of snacks, errands, and chatter into a scene of panic within seconds.

episode.title: Morning Drops #42 - The Joy Of Learning
episode.description:
Hosted by Yasmin, this Morning Drop explores learning as a lifelong process, focusing on persistence, repetition, and the emotional landscape that comes with challenging oneself over time.

Through personal stories and scientific insights, the episode looks at how learning reshapes the brain, generates joy through effort, and why progress often arrives after confusion and frustration. It reflects on the so-called delayed pleasure effect, the role of dopamine in motivation, and how curiosity and learning support long-term wellbeing.

The episode also questions our cultural relationship with failure and invites a softer, more realistic approach to learning, one that accepts mistakes as part of growth and sees persistence as a quiet form of strength.

Mood: reflective, grounded, quietly hopeful
Music genre: alternative rock, hip hop, electronic, neo-soul, drill

A space to listen slowly and stay with the process.

queue.fact_text: On 21 February 1994, CIA officer Aldrich Ames was arrested in a Virginia suburb after years of selling secrets to the Soviet Union and Russia. For less than US$3 million, he betrayed the identities of numerous U.S. agents, causing some to be executed and earning a place among the most damaging spies in American history.

queue.fact_text: On 21 February 1972, U.S. President Richard Nixon landed in Beijing, becoming the first sitting American president to visit the People’s Republic of China. His week‑long trip, carefully choreographed with symbolism and photo opportunities, helped end decades of silence between two global powers who had barely spoken since 1949.

queue.fact_text: On 21 February 1896, the World Heavyweight boxing title was decided in a makeshift ring near Ciudad Juárez, technically on Mexican soil to skirt U.S. restrictions. Bob Fitzsimmons, an Englishman raised in Australia, knocked out Irishman Peter Maher in under two minutes, turning a dusty border location into the world’s temporary boxing capital.

queue.fact_text: On 21 February 1862, Union and Confederate forces clashed near Fort Craig in the New Mexico Territory at the Battle of Valverde. It was part of the often‑overlooked New Mexico Campaign, where the Civil War briefly spilled into desert mesas and river crossings far from the better‑known eastern battlefields.

queue.fact_text: On 21 February 1828, the first issue of the *Cherokee Phoenix* rolled off the press, becoming the first newspaper printed in a Native American language. It used the newly invented Cherokee syllabary created by Sequoyah, turning an oral tradition into a printed one and linking Indigenous news, politics, and poetry in a single bilingual publication.

queue.fact_text: On 21 February 1808, Russian troops crossed into Sweden near Abborfors without a formal declaration of war, beginning the Finnish War. Within a year, Sweden would lose Finland, which became an autonomous Grand Duchy under Russia—setting the stage for modern Finnish identity to grow in the space between empires.

queue.fact_text: On 21 February 1613, a teenage Mikhail Romanov was elected Tsar by the Zemsky Sobor, ending Russia’s Time of Troubles and founding a dynasty that would rule for over 300 years. He initially wanted to refuse the crown, and legend says delegates had to track him down at a remote monastery to press the throne into his reluctant hands.

queue.fact_text: Beyond today’s list, music history also tags 21 February as the birthday of Nina Simone (born 1933), the classically trained pianist who fused jazz, soul, and protest into a single, unmistakable voice. She once said, “An artist's duty is to reflect the times,” and her songs became soundtracks to the U.S. Civil Rights Movement.

queue.fact_text: Another 21 February thread: in 1952, students in Dhaka, then in East Pakistan, were shot and killed while protesting for Bangla to be recognized as an official language. Their sacrifice is why UNESCO later declared 21 February International Mother Language Day, honoring the quiet power of speaking and learning in one’s own tongue.

queue.fact_text: On 21 February 1959, the Daytona 500 ran its inaugural race on the new Daytona International Speedway, turning a Florida beach‑town tradition of racing on sand into a high‑banked, high‑speed oval spectacle. A photo finish so close it took three days to declare the winner helped cement NASCAR’s most famous race from its very first lap.
